repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Currently, if a tree includes multiple disconnected ranges, and a highlight spans across multiple ranges, it will be applied in-between the ranges as well.

Fixed this by calculating intersection between the highlight range and the tree range, and adding multiple extmarks with these ranges.

What should happen if a highlight has `conceal`? Should everything in-between be concealed or not? In this PR currently clips them, so in-between areas aren't concealed.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -194,4 +194,36 @@ function M.add_bytes(source, range)
   return { start_row, start_col, start_byte, end_row, end_col, end_byte }
 end
 
+---Compute intersection of a given range with the array of ranges.
+---Ranges are end-exlcusive.

comment_data.body:
A table of `Range`s is a `Region`, and I think the naming should reflect that. (Looking forward, we'll need a proper abstraction for regions (e.g., block selections) anyway, so we should start laying the groundwork for that.)

Since this is called as `Range:...`, I would suggest `get_intersection` (can be extended to `Range[]` later).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -194,4 +194,36 @@ function M.add_bytes(source, range)
   return { start_row, start_col, start_byte, end_row, end_col, end_byte }
 end
 
+---Compute intersection of a given range with the array of ranges.
+---Ranges are end-exclusive.
+---@private
+---@param it Range4
+---@param ranges Range4[] Sorted, non-intersecting.
+---@returns Range4[]
+function M.clip_range4_arr4(it, ranges)

comment_regular_data.body:
> What should happen if a highlight has conceal? Should everything in-between be concealed or not? In this PR currently clips them, so in-between areas aren't concealed.

I'd say it should not, so this PR behaves correctly.
I assume the tests don't pass on  `master`? Then the commits need to be squashed (every commit to master should pass tests, for bisecting if nothing else).

Or:
- reorder commits
- we merge with a merge commit (or squash) instead of rebase, so there's an atomic point in master where CI passes.

Either works (although we tend to add tests to fix commits, so that would be the more usual approach -- and also easier for bisecting (since fewer commits, and no merge commits that need to be skipped)).

Let's just squash-merge. 

I would appreciate if someone could tell me which of the many open combined injection PRs are still relevant and how they depend on each other.

I wonder how I didn't notice. There's already an open pull request https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32549 that fixes the same issue.

Should I close this?

From a cursory look, your implementation looks much simpler and therefore preferable (if it fixes the same issues -- can you comment on that, and possibly include the alternative tests as well if they increase the testing surface)?

@ribru17

This pr looks really good, I can close/rework mine 👍the one thing this one is missing is clipping the regions from the language tree side as well, otherwise sometimes combined injections will not parse properly ( I *think* I have test coverage of this in my pr)

Turns out tree regions also need to be clipped to their parent's regions. It is a separate issue, and one that needs to be fixed before this one. My PR doesn't fix it. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32549 does.

I can't include multiline tests, since fixes for multiline combined injection (either of: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32619,  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31853, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31812, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32569) are open.
Could someone please open a tracking issue about combined injections and link the various PRs to the respective subissues? This would make it much easier to reason about and plan this.

I assume it shouldn't be me, so here's what I know:

I.
Highlights from a tree can appear both in front and behind highlights with the same priority of:
1. ancestor trees, 
2. sibling trees (of the same language, and of a different language)
3. regular extmarks

If the given highlight is multiline, and other highlight was added on line 2+ of the given highlight.

This is easiest to see with combined injections, since the highlight can span across unrelated highlights from parent trees.

Possible fixes:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31812 - offset child highlights by internal subpriority. Priorities stay the same. Fixes issues with both ancestor trees and regular extmarks. Can be extended to siblings
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31853 - offset child highlights by priority. Mostly fixes issues with both ancestor trees and regular extrmarks. Can be extended to siblings
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32569 - create new highlights iterator for each line. Fixes issue with ancestor and sibling trees. Potential performance problem
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32619 - Store relevant highlights and reapply them for each line. Fixes issue with ancestor and sibling trees.

Merging either of them will surface a limitation that parent highlights sometimes need to be in front of child highlights. Example is template string literals. The interpolated expression should be on top of all children.

II.

Child trees can include ranges outside their parent's region. This can happen if a (parent) combined injection contains another (child) combined injection, and the match for child injection was split across multiple ranges of parent injection.

Possible fixes:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32549 - clip child tree region to parent trees regions. (This is not correct? It should only clip against one parent tree that the match belongs to)

III.

Highlights of a child tree can appear outside their region. This can happen if a highlight spans across multiple ranges of the tree.

Requires II is fixed. Harder to test without fixing I.

Possible fixes:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32549 - Clip highlight ranges to tree region.
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32624 - same as previous.

IV.

(Theoretical) Combined child injection trees might not be created. Tree sitter requires ranges in tree region to be sorted and non-intersecting. Currently the ranges are passed in the encounter order, so nothing guarantees they will not intersect or be sorted.

Thank you (and you assume wrong ;))!

Template languages are a non-goal for now, since that is a broader tree-sitter issue common across all editors that needs a good answer from their side; the fundamental injection paradigm just doesn't fit that use case.

> Template languages are a non-goal for now,

I think maybe template here just meant to refer to template strings, e.g. `` `string text ${expression} string text` `` in javascript, I could be wrong though

> (This is not correct? It should only clip against one parent tree that the match belongs to)

~Just pushed a fix for this to #32549, feel free to pull that in here if you like/it works :+1:~

Edit: nevermind the two pointer approach I put in doesn't work lol, keep using your helper function here

title: fix(treesitter): clip combined injection highlights to tree range
